# `r config$publication_sub_name` {.toc-ignore}

Published `r config$publication_date`

## Key findings (2023/24)

### NHS Low Income Scheme {.toc-ignore}

The number of applications and issued certificates in 2023/24 was a slight decrease from 2022/23 but higher than the 2 years prior. There were 161,000 HC2 certificates and 87,000 HC3 certificates issued in 2023/24.

Certificates were most commonly issued to people from the younger (15-24) and older (65+) age groups. Looking at deprivation, limited to applications within England, certificates were most commonly issued to people from the most deprived areas of the country.

### Maternity exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

The number of applications and certificates issued has risen each year since 2020/21. There were 552,000 maternity exemption certificates issued in 2023/24.

Almost three-quarters of maternity exemption certificates issued in 2023/24 were valid for a period of 19 or more months. Less than 5% of certificates issued were valid for a period of 12 months or less and therefore issued close to, or after, the birth of the child.

The number of maternity exemption certificates issued in the most deprived areas is a little lower than may be expected based on the distribution of live births.

### Medical exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

The number of applications and certificates issued has risen following a drop between 2019/20 and 2021/22. There were 475,000 medical exemption certificates issued in 2023/24.

The number of certificates issued typically rises with age.

### NHS Prescription Prepayment Certificate (PPC) {.toc-ignore}

The number of PPCs purchased has increased in each of the past 5 years. The 12-month certificate is more popular than the 3-month certificate, with 2.1 million 12-month certificates issued in 2023/24 compared to 936,000 3-month certificates issued.

The number of certificates issued typically rises with age.

The number of PPCs issued is slightly lower in the most and least deprived areas of England. 

### NHS Hormone Replacement Therapy Prescription Prepayment Certificate (HRT PPC) {.toc-ignore}

The HRT PPC was launched in April 2023, with 131,000 certificates being issued in the first month. This represents 23% of the 566,000 certificates issued in 2023/24.

The number of certificates issued was higher in the less deprived areas. This relationship is similar to the pattern seen for patient's receiving prescribing of drugs licensed to treat menopause in the UK which are covered by the HRT PPC.

The South West region has some of the largest rates of HRT PPCs issued.

### NHS tax credit exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

The number of NHS tax credit exemption certificates has been declining for a number of years. As part of the Universal Credit rollout people are being migrated away from tax credits and onto new benefit schemes. In 2023/24, 1.2 million certificates were issued, compared to 3.7 million in 2018/19.

The age profile of recipients has changed over the past few years. In 2018/19, 55% of certificates were issued to people aged under 40 years old but in 2023/24 this has dropped to 30% of issued certificates.

## 1. Things you should know

### 1.1. Scope {.toc-ignore}

`r infoBox_border("Background",text = "The NHSBSA administer a range of services to help people with their health costs, including help with:

* NHS prescription costs
* NHS dental costs
* sight tests, glasses and contact lenses
* travel to receive NHS treatment
* NHS wigs and fabric supports

Full details of these schemes are available on the [NHS Help with Health Costs webpage](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-help-health-costs).

Six different certificate schemes are available, with different levels of help with health costs:

* [NHS Low Income Scheme (LIS)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme)
* [Maternity exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/check-if-you-have-nhs-exemption/maternity-exemption-certificates)
* [Medical exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/check-if-you-have-nhs-exemption/medical-exemption-certificates)
* [NHS Prescription Prepayment certificate     (PPC)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/help-nhs-prescription-costs/nhs-prescription-prepayment-certificate-ppc)
* [NHS Hormone Replacement Therapy Prescription Prepayment Certificate (HRT     PPC)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/help-nhs-prescription-costs/nhs-hormone-replacement-therapy-prescription-prepayment-certificate-hrt-ppc)
* [NHS Tax credit exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/exemption-certificates/nhs-tax-credit-exemption-certificates)"
, width = "100%")`

These statistics provide estimates of volumes related to these certificate schemes. Data covers the financial years 2018/2019 to 2023/24, where the financial year runs from April 1 to March 31.

These statistics are based on information from applications and data captured during certificate processing activities. Therefore, where information has not been supplied or captured accurately, this may impact the quality of the statistics.

Figures have been reported split by individual help with health cost service. Although an individual could use multiple services it is not possible to link individuals across the different service areas. Therefore figures should not be combined across service areas as the same individual could be represented multiple times.

Figure are presented based on the number of applications and issued certificates. Figures should not be interpreted as a number of people as a unique individual could be represented multiple times.

Some of the help with health cost services covered in this publication are provided only for residents in England while some services are also provided for other countries in the United Kingdom. Within this summary report figures will represent all activity, with additional breakdowns by country available in the supporting datasets.

## 2. Results and commentary

### 2.1 NHS Low Income Scheme

`r infoBox_border("",text = "The NHS Low Income Scheme (LIS) provides income related help. Support is available for people who do not receive help with health costs via an existing exemption. This is a means tested benefit, but also considers council tax and housing costs.

NHS Low Income Scheme exemption provides help with:

* NHS prescriptions
* NHS dental treatment
* sight tests, glasses and contact lenses
* travel to receive NHS treatment
* NHS wigs and fabric supports

The amount of support provided is based on weekly income, necessary outgoings, plus any savings or investments. Issued certificates will also cover the applicant's partner and dependent children under 20 years old.

The majority of activity is for applicants from England, however applications are also processed for applicants from Scotland and Wales."
, width = "100%")`

Applicants will either complete a paper HC1 form or apply via the [online application for LIS](https://apply-for-help-with-nhs-costs.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/apply-online).

Applications will include new applicants and existing certificate holders reapplying. The number of applications will also include incomplete applications.

Applications to the NHS Low Income Scheme decreased slightly in 2023/24, with 376,000 applications compared to 382,000 applications in 2022/23. Despite this decrease, the number of applications received are still higher than previous years.

Applications to the NHS Low Income Scheme are assessed to determine if the applicant qualifies for any support.

Two levels of support are available from the NHS Low Income Scheme. Depending on the outcome of the assessment, applicants could receive:

* an [HC2 certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme/hc2-certificates-full-help-health-costs) for full help with health costs, including free NHS prescriptions
* an [HC3 certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme/hc3-certificates-limited-help-health-costs) for limited help with health costs, which will show how much the holder has to pay towards health costs

There were 249,000 certificates issued in 2023/24. This included 161,000 HC2 certificates and 87,100 HC3 certificates. Compared to 2022/23 there has been a slight decrease in the number of certificates issued to customers. 

The amount of support with health costs provided by a HC3 certificate will vary based on outcome of the financial assessment. In some circumstances the amount stated on the HC3 certificate, that the holder has to pay towards health costs, may exceed maximum cost of NHS dental treatment. The proportion of HC3s issued where the contribution amount is above these levels has increased over the past few years from 13% of HC3s in 2028/19 to 33% of HC3s issued in 2023/24.

A certificate is only issued to the applicant following the completion of the assessment. Therefore these figures will not include any applications that are ongoing or were abandoned before completion. These figures will also exclude any completed applications where no certificate was issued to the applicant.

Active certificates measures the number of certificates valid in the specified financial year. Some NHS Low Income Scheme certificates can be valid up to 5 years. Therefore, the number of active certificates are higher than the certificates issued. 

When certificates expire a certificate holder could reapply, and then will have 2 (or more) certificates that have been active within a single financial year.

The number of active certificates is only available from 2019/20 due to retention schedules for certificates prior to this period. It should be noted that active certificates are based solely on the start and expiration date of the issued certificates. This does not consider if the certificate holder was using the certificate or not.

Trends in active certificates are generally in line with certificates issued. In 2023/24 there were 358,000 HC2 certificates active and 196,000 active HC3 certificates.

The duration of NHS Low Income Scheme certificates can vary from a little as a day to a maximum length of 5 years. 

The circumstances of the applicant will determine the duration of the certificate. This will reflect the chances of circumstances changing, with some common scenarios:

* Pensioners receiving full help may receive a 5 year certificate.
* Non final-year students may receive a 12 month certificate.
* Applicants in receipt of non-means tested benefit may receive a 12 month certificate.
* Applicants earning a wage may receive a 6 month certificate.
* Students nearing the end of their course may receive a short term certificate until the end of their course.

Almost 75,700 HC3 certificates, issued in 2023/24, were valid for a period of 12 months. This represents almost 87% of all HC3 certificates issued in 2023/24. HC2 certificates show more variation in length than HC3 certificates. In 2023/24 43,300 HC2 certificates were valid for 6 months and 92,300 were valid for 12 months.

[Section 3.3 of this summary](#about_imd) contains more information on this measure. Certificates were issued in the most deprived areas more than 3 times more often than the least deprived areas. In the most deprived areas, people may be more likely to qualify for other income-related benefits that offer some of the same support as available through the NHS Low Income Scheme.

Despite being means-tested, certificates are still issued to applicants from less deprived areas. In 2023/24, over 13,000 HC2 certificates and over 8,000 HC3 certificates went to the least deprived areas.

ICB areas have been used to allow comparisons between areas, however ICBs are not responsible for applications to the NHS Low Income Scheme. Applicants have been aligned to an ICB area based on their postcode, which is only possible for applicants within England.

Population estimates use figures published by [Office for National Statistics for ICB population](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/clinicalcommissioninggroupmidyearpopulationestimates). These figures are mid-year estimates with 2022 population estimates used for this report. These are the latest available population statistics at the time of publication. To align with the people who may benefit from the NHS Low Income Scheme, population figures are based on people aged 16 and over.

North West London ICB had the highest estimated number of certificates issued per 10,000 population. In 2023/24, an estimated 85 certificates were issued per 10,000 population in this ICB. North London had 3 of the top 4 ICBs in terms of certificates issued per 10,000 population.

Bath and North East Somerset, Swindon and Wiltshire ICB had the lowest estimated number of certificates issued per 10,000 population in 2023/24. This ICB had an estimated 29 certificates per 10,000 population.

Applications are submitted via a midwife, doctor or health visitor who confirms eligibility. Both paper and digital applications are available.

As a maternity exemption certificate provides support with NHS prescription charges, support is generally applicable to applicants from England only."

* a permanent fistula (for example, caecostomy, colostomy, laryngostomy or ileostomy) which needs continuous surgical dressing or an appliance
* a form of hypoadrenalism (for example, Addisonâ€™s Disease) for which specific substitution therapy is essential
* diabetes insipidus and other forms of hypopituitarism
* diabetes mellitus, except where treatment is by diet alone
* hypoparathyroidism
* myasthenia gravis
* myxoedema (hypothyroidism which needs thyroid hormone replacement)
* epilepsy which needs continuous anticonvulsive therapy
* a continuing physical disability which means you cannot go out without the help of another person
* cancer and are undergoing treatment for either:
  * cancer
  * the effects of cancer
  * the effects of cancer treatment

A GP or doctor can provide the application form to qualifying patients. Medical exemption certificates are usually valid for 5 years. Certificates will not be automatically renewed upon expiration, with certificate holders needing to reapply.

## 3 About these statistics

### 3.1 Statistical Disclosure Control (SDC) {.toc-ignore}

Statistical disclosure control has been applied to these statistics. Volume figures have been redacted in the supporting summary tables if they relate to fewer than 5 items. Further information about our statistical disclosure control protocol [can be found on our website](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/policies-and-procedures).

### 3.2. Rounding {.toc-ignore}

The high-level figures in this statistical summary have been rounded where appropriate for clarity. In most cases rounding has been to 2 significant figures in the key findings and information boxes and 3 significant figures in the main text. This is to make this narrative as accessible as possible to all readers. The summary tables released with this publication allow users to investigate this data at lower levels of granularity. Figures in the supplementary tables have not been rounded.

### 3.3. Index of deprivation {#about_imd .toc-ignore}

The [English Indices of Deprivation 2019](https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/english-indices-of-deprivation-2019) have been used to provide a measure of deprivation. The English Indices of Deprivation are an official national measure of deprivation that follows an established methodological framework to capture a wide range of individuals' living conditions.

The reported IMD quintile, where 1 is the most deprived and 5 the least deprived, is derived from the postcode currently held for an applicant. There are a small number of records each year that we have reported as having an unknown IMD quintile. These are applicants with no fixed abode or with british forces addresses, or where we have been unable to match the applicant postcode to an English postcode in the [National Statistics Postcode Lookup (NSPL) - May 2023](https://geoportal.statistics.gov.uk/datasets/379c875939ec4fc4bb48ed32711eb042/about).

IMD quintiles are calculated by ranking census lower-layer super output areas (LSOAs) from most deprived to least deprived and dividing them into equal groups. These range from the most deprived 20% (quintile 1) of small areas nationally to the least deprived 20% (quintile 5) of small areas nationally.
